isis.stitle: TSI 06-12-19 - Air Sensing Viscous Fan Drive Diagnostic Test Procedure

subjectgroup.subject: Air Sensing Viscous Fan Drive Diagnostic Test Procedure

geninfo.para: A correctly operating air sensing viscous fan drive may be misdiagnosed as faulty using the procedures previously available. To reduce the number of misdiagnosed viscous fan drives, perform the updated service procedure that follows.

warning.para: To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, read all safety instructions in the S12002Y service manual regarding use, application, or modification of a viscous fan drive and/or the fan it carries.
To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, DO NOT operate a vehicle with a fan drive or fan blades that are malfunctioning or damaged.
To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, DO NOT attempt to restrict fan blade rotation during engine operation.
To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, comply with the following before performing tests on the fan drive:

item.para: Shift transmission to park or neutral, set parking brake, and block wheels.
Wear safety glasses with side shields.
Do not wear loose clothing that can come into contact with the rotating fan blades.
Protect test leads from contact with rotating components.

svcproc.title: For snap action bi-metal or Coil VISCOUS FAN DRIVE TEST PROCEDURE (air sensing viscous DRIVES ONLY)

note.para: This test is most effective at an ambient air temperature of 80°F (26.7°C) or higher.
The engine must be off for Steps 1 through 8.

step1.para: Check the torque of fan blade fasteners. Refer to Table 1, Torque Chart.
Check the torque of fan drive-to-pulley, hub and bracket assembly fasteners.
Check the torque of pulley, hub and bracket assembly-to-engine fasteners.

Check the fan drive, fan blade assembly, shroud, radiator and the immediately adjacent areas for evidence of interference between rotating and non-rotating parts. If damage is present, isolate and repair the problem and replace damaged parts.

Rotate the fan, by hand, through at least 360 degrees. It should turn smoothly, but with some internal resistance. Replace fan drive if it binds, jerks, or spins freely. Insure the fan does not contact other objects.

note.para: The following step is used to detect looseness in the fan or fan drive mounting; when performing the Step, do not force the blade tip (cause the blade to deflect) because this will distort the resulting measurement.

step1.para: Grasp one fan blade tip, and apply fore and aft pressure. At 10 inches (254 mm) radius from the center, the blade tip should not move more than 1/16 inch (1.6 mm). If the blade moves more than specified and the excess cannot be attributed to pulley/water pump bearing wear, fan blade deflection, or loose fasteners (fan to fan drive or fan drive to hub/pulley), replace the fan drive.

Check for obstructions in the radiator, charge air cooler, air conditioning condenser, and transmission cooler (if equipped). Remove any dirt, bugs, lint, or debris in the air path through the radiator to the engine. Pressure wash if necessary.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death, wear heat protective gloves and safety glasses when working with hot liquids and objects.

caution.para: To avoid property damage, DO NOT direct high-pressure spray onto the fan drive bi-metal. High-pressure sprays must be directed squarely at the front, or rear, of the radiator and other coolers to prevent fin damage. Bent fin or fin damage will negatively affect air flow and/or cooling capacity of the radiator and other coolers.

step1.para: Ensure the cooling system is properly filled with the correct coolant mixtures (not to exceed 60% ethylene glycol).

note.para: In the following Step, warming up a cold engine prior to test preparation will shorten the run-time during the test procedure.

step1.para: If engine is cold, start engine and:

item.para: turn heater OFF (NOTE: on buses, turn heater supply valves OFF at the engine),
run until thermostat opens; then, turn engine OFF.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death when working near a hot engine wear protective clothing and heat protective gloves.

note.para: In the following Step, nylon fan blades (yellow in color) may require painting with flat black paint in order to measure fan speed.

step1.para: Apply a strip of reflective tape to one (1) blade of the fan and another strip to the fan drive shaft so that fan RPM and fan drive shaft RPM can be measured with the digital photo-tachometer ( Figure 1).

calloutgroup.callout1: 2. Reflective tape on fan drive shaft

step1.para: Connect EZ-Tech service tool. If testing a non-electronic engine, measure coolant temperature with an accurate thermometer.

Fabricate a cardboard cover that covers the entire frontal area of the radiator. Cut a 5 inch (12.7 cm) hole in the area that aligns directly in front of the fan drive bi-metal switch or coil. Position the cardboard in front of the radiator and tape as necessary to hold in place.

Carefully position the temperature probe so that it measures air temperature within 1 inch (2.54 cm) of the fan drive bi-metal or coil. You can safely insert the probe through the A/C condenser, CAC, and radiator core ( Figure 2 and Figure 3) .

figure.caption: Figure 2. Temperature Probe Inserted through Cardboard and Front of Radiator

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. Temperature probe must be positioned in this area [1 inch (2.54 cm) from bi-metal].

step1.para: Start the engine and:

item.para: recheck to ensure the air conditioning and heater are still OFF (on buses, turn heater supply valves OFF),

note.para: In the following Step the fan drive shaft speed is not the same as engine speed.

step1.para: Raise the engine speed until the fan drive shaft reaches 2500 RPM (measured with digital photo-tach). Do not measure fan speed yet.

note.para: Bright sunlight may make it difficult to read RPM measurements using the photo-tachometer.

step1.para: Lock the throttle at this RPM (use PTO/cruise switches if available). This establishes the fan drive shaft TEST RPM.

note.para: If engine cannot achieve 2500 RPM fan drive shaft input speed, test at the highest obtainable RPM.

step1.para: Measure fan blade speed with the digital photo-tachometer ( Figure 4).

figure.caption: Figure 4. Measuring Fan Blade Speed with Digital Photo-Tachometer

note.para: If the vehicle is equipped with shutters, they should open automatically before the fan drive engages.

step1.para: As the engine is warming up:

step2.para: The fan RPM should stabilize between 700 and 1100 RPM. Some DD-30 and DD-34 fan drives may stabilize at up to 1300 RPM.
As engine coolant temperature reaches 200-220°F (93.3-104.4°C) (Figure 5), fan speed should increase to 85% or more of the fan shaft RPM.

The air temperature at the bi-metal or coil should be between 165°F (73.9°C) and 195°F (90.6°C) when the fan engages ( Figure 5). Refer to the Borg Warner attachment in the pdf for this TSI
for specific fan drive P/N calibration information.

figure.caption: Figure 5. Measuring the Coolant and Air Temperatures

step1.para: With the fan engaged, record fan RPM, coolant temperature, and air temperature at bi-metal or coil.

Maintain the TESTRPM, with the fan engaged, by keeping the engine speed constant. Remove the cardboard cover from the cooling module. As temperatures decrease, fan speed should begin to decrease. After 2-3 minutes the fan should slow to the initial fan speed (approximately 700 to 1100 RPM).
Allow fan to repeat this cycle several times while recording temperatures and fan RPM, utilizing cardboard cooling module cover as required to force fan drive engagement.
If the fan fails to reach 85% of input speed at 200 - 220°F (93.3-104.4°C) coolant temperature, and the air temperature at the bi-metal exceeds 195°F (90.6°C), replace the viscous fan drive.

If the fan fails to reach 85% of fan input speed, and the coolant temperature exceeds 220°F (104.4°C), and the air temperature at the bi-metal or coil does not exceed 195°F (90.6°C); then the fan drive is not faulty. Inspect the vehicle for the following:

step2.para: Air flow restrictions (through the CAC and radiator)
Refer to TSI-05-12-34 for additional diagnostic information

step1.para: When the fan drive disengages (with the 2500 TEST RPM maintained), if the fan speed fails to slow to 700-1100 RPM; replace the fan drive (except DD-30 and DD-34 which could be in the 1300 RPM range).
Remove the air temperature sensing probe from the radiator.
Remove the cardboard from the front of the radiator.
Return the engine to "idle" and allow the engine to cool for two (2) minutes before shutting down.

item.para: Engagement air temperatures indicate test cell calibration and may vary in the vehicle.
Bi-metal and coil fan drives will have a gradual engagement speed until the fan is fully in the modulated ON position.

note.para: The fasteners MUST be S.A.E. Grade #8 or better.
